current-chamber.#text: IN THE SENATE OF THE UNITED STATES

official-title.#text:
To amend the Homeland Security Act of 2002 to direct the Administrator of the Federal Emergency
			 Management Agency to modernize the integrated public alert and warning
			 system of the United States, and for other purposes.

committee-name.#text: Committee on Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs

cosponsor.#tail: ) introduced the following bill; which was read twice and referred to the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Integrated Public Alert and Warning System Modernization Act of 2014
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Integrated Public Alert and Warning System Modernization Act of 2014

text.#text: This Act may be cited as the

header.#text: Integrated public alert and warning system modernization

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
is amended by adding at the end
			 the following:

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Title V of the Homeland Security Act of 2002
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Homeland Security Act of 2002/t:V
usc/6/311/etseq

header.#text: Integrated public alert and warning system modernization

text.#text:
To provide timely and effective warnings regarding natural disasters, acts of terrorism, and other
			 man-made disasters or threats to public safety, the

quote.#tail: ) to help ensure that under all conditions the

text.#text:
modernize the integrated public alert and warning system of the United States (in this section
			 referred to as the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
and, except to the extent the public
			 alert and
			 warning system is in use by the

, Federal agencies and State,
			 tribal, and local governments can alert and warn the civilian population
			 in areas endangered by natural disasters, acts of terrorism, and other
			 man-made disasters or threats to public safety; and

text.#text:
implement the public alert and warning system to disseminate timely and effective warnings and
			 homeland security information regarding natural disasters, acts of
			 terrorism, and other man-made disasters or threats to public safety.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Homeland Security Act of 2002/s:526/ss:a

text.#text: In carrying out

establish or adopt, as appropriate, common alerting and warning protocols, standards, terminology,
			 and operating procedures for the public alert and warning system;

include in the public alert and warning system the capability to alert, warn, and provide
			 equivalent information to individuals with disabilities, individuals with
			 access and functional needs, and individuals with limited-English
			 proficiency, to the extent technically feasible;

ensure that training, tests, and exercises are conducted for the public alert and warning system,
			 including by—
incorporating the public alert and warning system into other training and exercise programs of the

establishing and integrating into the National Incident Management System a comprehensive and
			 periodic training program to instruct and educate Federal, State, tribal,
			 and local government officials in the use of the Common Alerting Protocol
			 enabled Emergency Alert System; and

conduct public education efforts so that State, tribal, and local governments, private entities,
			 and the people of the United States reasonably understand the functions of
			 the public alert and warning system and how to access, use, and respond to
			 information from the public alert and warning system through a general
			 market awareness campaign;

consult, coordinate, and cooperate with the appropriate private sector entities and Federal, State,
			 tribal, and local governmental authorities, including the Regional
			 Administrators and emergency
			 response providers; and

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text:
Integrated Public Alert and Warning System
			 Subcommittee
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Integrated Public Alert and Warning System Subcommittee
Integrated Public Alert and Warning System Modernization Act of 2014/s:2/ss:b

short-title.#text: Integrated Public Alert and Warning System Modernization Act of 2014

text.#text: coordinate with and consider the recommendations of the
The public alert and warning system shall—
to the extent determined appropriate by the

be designed to adapt to, and incorporate, future technologies for communicating directly with the
			 public;
to the extent technically feasible, be designed—

to provide alerts to the largest portion of the affected population feasible, including nonresident
			 visitors and tourists, individuals with disabilities, individuals with
			 access and
			 functional needs, and individuals with limited-English proficiency; and
to improve the ability of remote areas to receive alerts;

promote local and regional public and private partnerships to enhance community preparedness and
			 response;

provide redundant alert mechanisms where practicable so as to reach the greatest number of people;
			 and
to the extent feasible, include a mechanism to ensure the protection of individual privacy.

Except to the extent necessary for testing the public alert and warning system, the public alert
			 and warning system shall not be used to transmit a message that does not
			 relate to a natural disaster, act of terrorism, or other man-made disaster
			 or threat to public safety.
Nothing in this section shall be construed to supersede

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: section 602 of the SAFE Port Act
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: SAFE Port Act/s:602

text.#text: in developing the recommendations under

recommendations for common alerting and warning protocols, standards, terminology, and operating
			 procedures for the public alert and warning system; and
recommendations to provide for a public alert and warning system that—

has the capability to adapt the distribution and content of communications on the basis of
			 geographic location, risks, or personal user preferences, as appropriate;

has the capability to alert and warn individuals with disabilities and individuals with
			 limited-English proficiency;
to the extent appropriate,  incorporates multiple communications technologies;

is designed to adapt to, and incorporate, future technologies for communicating directly with the
			 public;

promotes local and regional public and private partnerships to enhance community preparedness and
			 response; and

provides redundant alert mechanisms, if practicable, to reach the greatest number of people
			 regardless of whether they have access to, or use, any specific medium
			 of communication or any particular device.
